1.12 Expression interpreter

1.12.1 Overview

The following source code provides an implementation of an interpreter that able evaluate infix math expressions, with mathematics operator precendence rules, and programming constructs including if-else statements, while loop, for loop, function calls and function definition. The application is comprised of three parts a lexer and evaluator. The tokenizer, also known as tokenizer, is a component that breaks the source code into lexical units called tokens. In this case, a token is a struct containing the token lexeme, a string that represents the token; the token type enumeration, which indicates whether the token is a number, a keyword or a string; and metadata related to the token position, column and line in the source code. The parser component takes the token stream generated by the tokenizer as input and produces an AST - Abstract Syntax Tree using a recursive descent parsing algorithm that consists of mutually recursive functions, each implementing a non-terminal grammar symbol. The final part of the expression interpreter is an AST evaluator, that traverses the AST - Abstract Syntax Tree nodes generated by the parser in a recursive way for producing runtime values, that represents all possible computation results.

The techniques adopted in this sample code, can be used for implementing formula evaluators, spreadsheets, CAS - Computer Algebra Ssystems, DSL - Domain Specific Languages or embedded scripting languages for allowing extending applications at runtime. Despite that the C++ was used for implementing this interpreter, the algorithm can easily be implemented in any other programming language and rewritten in a more concise way in functional programming languages with pattern matching and algebraic data types. For instance, in a functional programming language, the visitor design pattern could be replaced by a more concise pattern matching and the class hierarchies representing the AST - Abstract Syntax Tree and interpreter runtime values could be replaced by algebraic data types.

This parser implements the following grammar stated in ANTLR-style EBNF (Extended Backnaur notation). The syntax of programming constructs were borrowed from Basic and Pascal programming languages. 

// Complete program - is a collection of zero or more statements 
prog: stat* ;

// Statement 
stat: expr ";"?          // Expression 
    | IDEN "=" expr ";"  // Assignment 
    | while_loop          
    | for_loop 
    ;

expr:        logical ;
logical:     equality ( ( "or" | "and" ) equality )* ;
equality:    comparison ( ( "!=" | "==" ) comparison )* ;
comparison:  arithmetic ( ( ">" | ">=" | "<" | "<=" ) arithmetic )* ;

arithmetic:  factor ( ("+" | "-") factor  )* ;
factor:      unary  ( ("*" | "/") unary   )* ;

unary: "+"  unary  
      | "-" unary  
      | "!" unary  
      | power 
      ;

power: call ("^" unary)*  ; // Exponentiation 

call: atom 
    | IDEN "(" ( expr ( "," expr )* )?  ")" // Function call 
    ;

atom  :  INTEGER         // number 
       | FLOATING_POINT 
       | IDEN            // Identifier, example function name or variable name   
       | BOOLEAN         // Logical value  
       | SYMBOL          // symbol like Lisp keyword or Ruby's symbols 
       | NIL             // null value 
       | "(" expr ")"
       | expr_if         // If-else statement 
       | expr_def        // Function definition  
       ;   

// IF-Else statement (NOT IMPLEMENTED)
expr_if: "if" expr "then" stat+ "end"
       | "if" expr "then" stat+ "else" stat+ "end"
       ;

// Function definition 
expr_def: "fn" IDEN "(" (IDEN  ("," IDEN)*)?  ")" stat* "end"
        | "fn" IDEN "(" (IDEN ("," IDEN)* ))? ")" "->" expr 
        ;

while_loop: "while" expr "do" stat* "end" ; 
for_loop:   "for" IDEN "=" expr "to" expr ("by" expr)? "do" stat* "end" ;

BOOLEAN: "true" | "false" ;
NIL:     "nil" ;
SYMBOL:  ":" ID ;

The expression parser is able to parse the following syntax: 

// Math expressions and formulas 
10 + 3 * 5 / (x + 2 * y + 4 * z) + exp(2.1) ^ 2 ^ 3 

// Numbers in percent 
30% // 0.30 

// Numbers with _ as thousand separator 
10_125_905 // 10125905

// Floating point numbers 
2.15e3 

if x > 0 then 
  print("x is positive")
else 
  print("x is negative or zero")
end 

x = 20

// Result z = 100 
z = if x > 10 then 
      5 * x 
    else 
      10 * x
    end 

for i = 1 to 10 do 
   print(" i = ", i)
end 

k = 10
while k > 0 do 
   print(" k = ", k)
   k = k - 1
end 

fn short_function(x) -> 3 * x + log10(x)

fn long_function(x, y, z)
   print(" x = ", x)
   print(" y = ", y)
   print(" z = ", z)
end

BNF - Backus-Naur and grammar-related terminology

  • CFG - Context-Free Grammar
    • As opposite to CSG - Context-Sensitive Grammars, production rules of CFG grammars does not depend on the context. This type of grammar can be described by BNF or EBFN notation.
  • CSG - Context-Sensitive Grammar
    • Grammar which production rules are context-sensitive and depends on the current context. The C and C++ programming languages grammars are context-sensitive, since the interpretation of many programming constructs are context-dependent. For instance, the meaning of T * X in C and are dependent on the context, if T is type, such as int, then X is a pointer variable. If both X and T are of type int, float or any other numeric type, then the expression is a multiplication between variables T and X.
  • CFG - Control Flow Graph
  • BNF - Backus-Naur Normal Form
    • Notation introduced by John Backus and Peter Naur for formally describing context-free grammars, which are not context-sensitive and not ambiguous. For instance C and C++ grammars are not context-free grammars since the meaning of an expressions depends on the context, whether the symbol is a function, pointer, class and so on.
  • EBNF - Extended Backus-Naur Form
  • ABNF - Augmented Backus-Naur Form
    • Modified Back-Naur Form notation for describing bidirectional communication protocols. This notation is used to describe the Http protocol, FTP protocol and other network protocols.
  • ANTLR - ANother Tool For Language Recognition
    • Open source tool written in Java that takes an ANTLR-style EBNF grammar and generates a parser for this grammar in a given target language, such as Python, Ruby, Perl, Go (Golang), Java, C# (CSharp), C, C++, JavaScript (ECMAScript), PHP and Swift. ANTLR is one of the most used tools for generating parsers and lexers/tokenizers. This parser generator tool has its own EBNF grammar style that does not conform to ISO/IEC 14977 technical standard.
  • Lex - Program that generates scanner/tokenizer/texer source code in C programming language.
  • Yacc - (Yet Another Compiler-Compiler) - Program, akin to ANTLR, that generates parser source code in C programming language. Yacc is often used alongside Lex (Lex & Yacc).
  • Flex (Lexical Analyser Generator) - GNU alternative to Lex.
  • GNU Bison - GNU alternative to Yacc. Ofen used together with Flex (Flex & Bison).
  • RE2C - Lexer code generator for C/C++, Go and Rust. This tool is used by PHP, Ninja build system and BRL-CAD.
  • Parsing - process of turning a string from text or source code into some data structure such as AST - Abstract Syntax Tree. Example, turning a string containing a JSON (Java-Script Object) notation code into a tree-like data structure.
  • AST - Abstract Syntax Tree
    • Data structure that describes a tree representation of the source code used as input of compiler code generators, bytecode code generators, interpreters and pretty printers.
  • DOM - Document Object Model
    • Abstract Syntax Tree representation of an XML or HTML document. Whenever a web page is loaded, the web browser turns the html code into a DOM object, a tree-like representatio the html source code that is exposed to the JavaScript (ECMaScript) code.
  • DAG - Direct Acyclic Graph
  • SEXP S-Expression from Lisp
    • Lisp S-expressions are one of the most convenient and compact to represent AST - Abstract Syntax Trees as text.
  • Top-down Recursive Descent Parsing or just Recursive Descent Parsing
    • Parser algorithm that uses mutually recursive functions or methods for each non-terminal production rule. Despite the simplicity of implementation of this parsing technique, it has few shortcomings such as not being able to deal with left-recursive and ambiguous grammars.
  • TDOP - Top-Down Operator Precedence Parser (the same as Pratt Parser)
    • Parser algorithm that can parse infix, prefix and postfix expressions different operator precedence levels without a non-terminal grammar rule for every precedence level. This algorithm is more flexible than Top-Down Recursive Descent Parsing since new operator precedence levels can be added without modifying the grammar or adding new recursive function.
  • Shunting-yard algorithm (Edsger Dijkstra)
    • This algorithm uses a stack for turning infix expressions into postfix expression, RPL - Reverse Polish Notation, which is suitable for direct evaluation of infix expressions. Unlike other algorithms, the output is not an AST - Abstract Syntax Tree. Therefore, if an AST is needed, an additional algorithm will be required for turning the postfix output into an AST.
  • LALR - Look Ahead Left-to-Right Rightmost derivation parser (Parser Algorithm)
  • DFA - Deterministic Finite Automaton
  • DSA - Deterministic Stack Automata (related to automata theory and formal languages)
  • NSA - Non-deterministic Stack Automata (related to automata theory and formal languages)
  • DSL - Domain Specific Language
  • GPL - General Purpose Language
  • CAS - Computer Algebra System
  • SAS - Symbolic Algebra System (Another name of CAS)
  • IR - Intermediate Representation
  • IL - Intermediate Language
  • EOI - End Of Input
  • EOF - End Of File
  • EOL - End Of Line
  • CR - Carriage Return - new line character (\r - 0x0D - 13)
  • LF - Line Feed - new line character (\n - 0x0A - 10)
  • CRLF - Carriage Return and Line Feed (\r\n)
  • LHS - Left-Hand Side, often the left-hand side of an infix operator such as (plus): lhs + rhs.
  • RHS - Right-Hand Side, often the right-hand side of an infix operator such as (star): lhs * rhs.
  • terminals - (ANTLR) are written with upper case letters, for instance, IDENTIFIER, NUMBER, …
    • A Terminal symbol is just a single token that represents an AST (Abstract Syntax Tree) node without any child AST nodes. For instance, terminal symbols are string literals; boolean literals (True, False in Python); integer literals; floating point literals and so on.
  • non-terminals - (ANTLR) are written using camel-case or snake-case convention. For instance: expr, program, for_loop.
    • A non-terminal symbol are symbols comprised of multiple terminal symbols or tokens. Non-terminal symbols correponds to AST - Abstract Syntax Tree nodes with multiple AST child nodes. For instance, non-terminal symbols are often if-else statement, for-loop statement, while-loop and so on.
  • '=' - ISO/IEC 14977 - definition of grammar production rules (non-terminals and terminals)
  • ':' - (ANTLR) - definition of grammar production rules
  • ':=' - defintion of grammar production rules - this notation is used by some EBNF grammar variants.
  • '*' - Kleene Star - means 0 or more occurences of a pattern
  • '+' - Kleene Cross - means 1 or more occurrences of a pattern
  • '?' - question mark - means 0 or 1 occurences of a pattern
  • ',' - (ISO/IEC 14977) - concatenation
  • '|' - (ISO/IEC 14977) alternation - separation between alternatives grammar production rules.
  • { … } - (ISO/IEC 14977) - repetition of 0 or more ocurrences - equivalent to (…)*
  • ( … ) - parentheses are used for grouping
  • " … " - terminal string
  • ' … ' - terminal string
  • (* … *) - (ISO/IEC 14977) - comment
  • // … - (ANTLR) comment
  • ';' - ANTLR used as delimiter of grammar production rules
  • '' - Epsilon - used in grammar descriptions for eliminating left-recursion by indicating an empty string. This notation is not used by EBFN, that uses an empty string instead of any special notation.

Performance Optimization for Interpreters

  • Compilation to virtual machine
    • Most programming languages interpreter engines do not execute AST nodes directly, instead they compile the source code to bytecodes, which are a instructions for some virtual machine.
  • Compilation to a standardized virtual machine
    • Rather than implementing its own bytecode virtual machine, a programming language may use standardized bytecode virtual machine runtimes that are not exposed to external use and not likely to have breaking changes on every release. Some of these virtual machines, that are a compilation target to many programming languages, are: JVM - Java Virtual Machine, used by Jython (Python for JVM), Clojure and Groovy; CRL - Commong Language Runtime (.NET Virtual Machine), use by C# (CSharp), F# (FSharp), IronPython; and WASM - Web Assembly.
  • JIT - Just-In-Time compilation
    • Compilation of bytecodes (virtual machine instructions) to machine code (also known as native code) at runtime. This processs combines the advantage of interpretation and compilation to native code. The shortcoming of this approach is the loss of flexibility and portability, since the JIT has to be ported to every processor architecture where the virtual machine will be deployed.
  • FFI - Foreign Function Interface
    • FFI allows loading native code shared libraries, which may be written in C, C++, Rust, D (Dlang), exposing a C interface and C symbols.
  • Native Extension API
    • A plugin system that allows loading libraries provided as shared libraries (*.so - files on Linux, BSD; *.dylib on MacOSX or *.dll on Windows), written in C, C++, Rust or any other language that compiles to native code, conforming to an expected C interface. Example: Java's JNI that allows loading Java Libraries written in C or C++ that conforms to the JNI API by using JNI SDK - Software Development Kit.
  • Choice and implementation of garbage collector algorithm
  • String Interning
  • Constant Folding
  • Constant Propagation
  • Escape Analysis
  • NaN Boxing

fn test_number(x)
  if x < 0  then print(" => x = ", x, " => negative ") end 
  if x == 0 then print(" => x = ", x, " => zero ")     end 
  if x > 0  then print(" => x = ", x, " => positive ") end 
end

test_number(20)
test_number(0)


print("\n---------- WHILE LOOP ----------- ")


fn do_sum(i)
  sum = 0;

  // Start  loop 
  while i > 0 do 
    i = i - 1;
    sum = sum + sq(i);
    print("\tsq(i) = ", sq(i));
  end 

  print("\tsum = ", sum);
  // The return value is the last function value 
  sum;                     
end 

sum = do_sum(5)

print(" sum = do_sum(5) =  ", sum)

print("\n---------- FOR LOOP  ----------- ")

for i = 10 to 0 by -2 do 
  print(" \t i = ", i, " ; i^2 = ", i * i) 
end
